 Oh AA, come on. The planet's crust is littered with transitional forms.
 
 A fossil isn't called transitional because we know for certain it's a direct descendent of one species and a direct ancestor of another. It's called transitional because it exhibits intermediate features or a combination of features, and because it's found at an appropriate level in the geological column relative to the forms to which it appears morphologically intermediate(and no, that's not the same as depth underground; uplift and erosion sees to that.) and in an appropriate geographical location.
 
 We have detailed fossil records showing both smooth species-species transitions and longer-term higher-order transitions. A couple of excerpts from the page I linked:
 
 
Rose & Bown (1984) analyzed over 600 specimens of primates collected from a 700-meter-thick sequence representing approximately 4 million years of the Eocene. They found smooth transitions between Teilhardina americana and Tetonoides tenuiculus, and also beween Tetonius homunculus and Pseudotetonius ambiguus.

 
Gingerich (summarized in 1977) traced two distinct species of lemur-like primates, Pelycodus frugivorus and P. jarrovii, back in time, and found that they converged on the earlier Pelycodus abditus "in size, mesostyle development, and every other character available for study, and there can be little doubt that each was derived from that species." Further work (Gingerich, 1980) in the same rich Wyoming fossil sites found species-to-species transitions for every step in the following lineage: Pelycodus ralstoni (54 Ma) to P. mckennai to P. trigonodus to P. abditus, which then forked into three branches. One became a new genus, Copelemur feretutus, and further changed into C. consortutus. The second branch became P. frugivorus. The third led to P. jarrovi, which changed into another new genus, Notharctus robinsoni, which itself split into at least two branches, N. tenebrosus, and N. pugnax (which then changed to N. robustior, 48 Ma), and possibly a third, Smilodectes mcgrewi (which then changed to S. gracilis). Note that this sequence covers at least three and possibly four genera, with a timespan of 6 million years.

 
Kurten (1976) describes bear transitions: "From the early Ursus minimus of 5 million years ago to the late Pleistocene cave bear, there is a perfectly complete evolutionary sequence without any real gaps. The transition is slow and gradual throughout, and it is quite difficult to say where one species ends and the next begins. Where should we draw the boundary between U. minimus and U. etruscus, or between U. savini and U. spelaeus? The history of the cave bear becomes a demonstration of evolution, not as a hypothesis or theory but as a simple fact of record." He adds, "In this respect the cave bear's history is far from unique."

 
Werdelin & Solounias (1991) wrote an extensive monograph on hyenids. They discuss over one hundred (!) named species, with extensive discussion of the eighteen best-known species, and cladistic analysis of hundreds of specimens from the SIXTY-ONE "reasonably well known" hyaenid fossil species. They concluded:
 
 "We view the evolution of hyaenids as overwhelmingly gradual. The species, when studied with regard to their total variability, often grade insensibly into each other, as do the genera. Large specimens of Hyaenotherium wongii are, for example, difficult to distinguish from small specimens of Hyaenictitherium hyaenoides, a distinct genus. Viewed over the entire family, the evolution of hyaenids from small, fox-like forms to large, scavenging, "typical" hyenas can be followed step by step, and the assembly of features defining the most derived forms has taken place piecemeal since the Miocene. Nowhere is there any indication of major breaks identifying macroevolutionary steps."

 Not that it's entirely your fault, mind you. The requirement for one mechanism, mutation, to explain every organismic change or adaptation has long been a misperception reinforced by pop culture, ever since that mechanism was first discovered. Your fault lies in clinging to that oversimplification, despite the earnest efforts of others to correct it, for no reason other than it panders to your desire for evolution not to fit the facts.
 
 For a start, there's no blanket dogma saying 'evolution = slow'. Evolution involves a number of layered and parallel processes, all influenced to different degrees by different external pressures and all operating on different timescales. Broadly speaking, these processes can be broken down according to whether they introduce new alleles, add new potential variation, realise potential variation, or reduce variation.
 
 Genetic mutation introduces new alleles - new or variant genes. Mutation rates are influenced by environmental mutagens and the time between generations, and also by the size of the population (bigger population = more mutations entering the gene pool). As an evolutionary mechanism it is at its most powerful and dynamic in bacteria, with their rapid reproductive rate and huge population sizes.
 
 Genetic mutation in sexually reproducing species also introduces new potential variation: the recombinatorial possibilities of that new gene with all the other variant alleles that exist, and potential interactions with environmental changes, like temperature, diet etc. Interbreeding, migration and environmental change all realise that potential variation, exploring the recombinatorial possibilities. This obviously happens on a much shorter timescale, and is influenced by size of population, patterns of interbreeding and, again, time between generations.
 
 Natural selection, in the form of competition for resources or predation, obviously acts to reduce variation, and can have a very rapid effect indeed - with immediate knock-on effects upon patterns of interbreeding and the recombinatorial potential thus explored.
 
 It's important to remember that the strength and direction of these various influences wax and wane, dramatically affecting the overall evolutionary rate of a species. If a population is large, well-adapted and interbreeds thoroughly within a fairly stable environment, the metaphorical foot is off the evolutionary gas-pedal. New alleles accumulate within the population, and interbreeding explores the recombinant potential, but there's no strong directional component. It's like a gradually expanding cloud of ever-richer genetic variation concentrated around the most successful combinations.
 
 However, a sudden environmental change can induce a powerful selective gradient across that peacefully expanding cloud. Variations that were value-neutral can overnight become statistically significant as they interact with novel circumstances - which obviously has a huge influence upon patterns of interbreeding in the next generation, naturally focusing recombination upon the most successful variants (here competition for mates and sexual selection acts to speed the process up even further), reinforcing those traits and inducing a kind of snowball effect of adaptation. And it's not just environmental change that can have that effect: physical segregation of a sub-population can set it adrift, no longer tied through interbreeding to the dominant combinations of 'fittest' alleles, and free to find a new 'best fit' in the absence of competition with those same 'fittest' genes.
 
 Equally dramatic explosions of variation can occur when a species encounters an environment with many empty niches. In Lake Victoria, for instance, a single species of cichlid found itself in a vast, brand new lake with abundant resources, no competition, and no predation to speak of. With natural selection temporarily on vacation the species radiated like mad - almost anything was viable. Subsequently, competition amongst the radiant subspecies imposed selective pressure and calmed things down again, with the result that over 300 species now inhabit various niches in the lake's ecosystem.
 
 So going back to the evidence I've linked to: it does not require millions of years, rather it (in places) indicates millions of years. No problem for evolutionary theory there; periods of stasis or slow drift are perfectly in line with expectations. You can even find, within the pages I linked, research that has positively correlated periods of evolutionary stasis followed by rapid change to environmental stasis followed by dramatic change (such as sudden widespread flooding). If you open your mind to the theory as it actually stands today, it's really very exciting just how well it fits with, predicts and explains a multitude of disparate observations. 
 
 Now let's look at the first example of rapid evolution you provided, the sticklebacks. Sure enough, on that very page:
 
The ability of the fish to quickly adapt to environmental changes such as increased predation by the cutthroat trout is due, Peichel believes, to their rich genetic variation. The sticklebacks in Lake Washington contain DNA from both marine (saltwater) fish, which tend to be fully plated, and freshwater sticklebacks, which tend to be low-plated. When environmental pressures called for increased plating, some of the fish had copies of genes that controlled for both low and full plating, and so natural selection favored the latter.

 In other words, the fish were already genetically diverse. The changing environmental circumstances applied a selective pressure which favoured one variant, which proliferated as the other variant suffered. Interbreeding patterns inevitably altered, plated fish bred with plated fish statistically more often, reinforcing the trend. Again, entirely in line with evolutionary theory. Here 'rapid evolution' is something that happened to the population as a whole, drastically changing the relative proportions of fish with different pre-existing traits, as opposed to 'rapid adaptation' by individuals.
 
 So let's look at the next example you posted. Once again, we find that the house finch species already possesses the necessary potential variability, only here in an even more immediately accessible form regulated by developmental timing. Quite what it is induces the mothers to lay in a particular order, or how they 'choose' the sex of their eggs, is a fascinating question, but it doesn't change the fact that the 'quick change' variability we're seeing is already inherent to their genetic payload, and has no implications for how fast other, different evolutionary processes ought to proceed - in particular, it says nothing about how quickly that adaptive mechanism itself came into existence. After all, the speed at which your TV changes channel is unrelated to the amount of time it's taken for us to develop television, right?
 
 The critique you linked to makes more or less the same mistake: trying to force evolution to be a single mechanism and then complaining when no single mechanism can explain every adaptation. We've had billions of years for adaptive mechanisms to layer one atop the other, each arising as a product of its precursors - of course unpicking them is a complex and difficult task. But that doesn't make the slightest difference to the mountain of mechanism-independent evidence that evolution has happened.

 As far as proof goes, as others have pointed out there are practical limits as to what can be directly proved - including our very existence. Science concerns itself with identifying the best candidate for the most accurate model of reality. As a model, seperate creation of all species is a very poor candidate for predicting the fossil record we actually see, whereas evolution is a phenomenally accurate model for predicting the fossil record we see - accurate enough that scientists were able to predict the features and strata of a fossil before it had ever been discovered. 
 
 It really isn't about proof. It's about deciding which hypothesis best fits the facts. There isn't one species for which we have a fossil pattern that fits the predictions of creationism (ie, broadly distributed throughout fossil-bearing strata), while on the other hand every single fossil ever found fits the predictions of evolution (ie, each species located within a relatively narrow and continuous range of strata, bracketed by similar transitional species, and forming part of a chronologically-ordered nested hierarchy of forms converging on a single common ancestor).
